stream_context.summary: Asset-building and debugging session focused on Course 11, an oil-rig level inspired by Rico Harbor; Kaze models new moving platforms, experiments with lighting, colours and fog, fixes a collision bug that broke ziplines, and sketches future mechanics such as cannons and a thermal plant.
level: brief tests in Koopa Wave Cove (Course 5)

development_findings.summary: Modelled a full set of modular platforms for Course 11: left-right movers, in-out sliders, shrinking platforms, rotating cranes, hooks, seesaws and future ziplines.
development_findings.quote: So this platform will move left and right… this one will shrink and grow… we’ve got quite a few.

development_findings.summary: Level aesthetic draws from Mario Sunshine’s Rico Harbor; uses recoloured textures but aims not to look like a direct copy.
development_findings.quote: They are recoloured Rico Harbor textures… I was hoping it wouldn’t be obvious that I’m being inspired by that.

development_findings.summary: Implemented ‘camera light’ (light aligned with the camera) after studying Mario Odyssey footage, making moving objects brighter and scenes easier to read.
development_findings.quote: I added the light coming from the camera back… makes the whole game look a lot brighter.

development_findings.summary: Discovered and fixed a months-old optimisation bug that offset ceiling raycasts, breaking ziplines; fix required correcting misplaced brackets in collision code.
development_findings.quote: I messed up the code and I actually never tested it… took me like five minutes, but it would have taken longer to test it.

development_findings.summary: Clip-ratio change gives 3–5 FPS on N64 but causes far-triangle ‘melting’; Kaze may revert if not worth debugging.
development_findings.quote: Clip ratio gives us a few more FPS, but it also causes all of this to happen.

development_findings.summary: Planning cannons that shoot between buildings; rejects visual trajectory lines to preserve player freedom.
development_findings.quote: Games should be about experiencing freedom… giving a line takes away all the skill.

development_findings.summary: Course 11 retro pipe will recreate Smash 64’s Break the Targets board.
development_findings.quote: The retro pipe will be Smash 64 board to platforms; it’s fitting because this is a very platformy course.

development_findings.summary: Future milestone: add split-screen multiplayer during a two-week work vacation at end of June.
development_findings.quote: In those two weeks, I might add multiplayer with split-screen.

development_findings.summary: Overall roadmap: Course 12 ‘Wild West Valley’, plus a comic-book world and a casino; Buzzer boss still awaiting animations.
development_findings.quote: We’re already in Course 11… next is Wild West Valley, a comic book world, a casino world.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is rewriting an optimised replacement for libultra and considers open-sourcing and back-porting engine optimisations later.
development_findings.quote: We don’t use libultra anymore; I’m making my own optimised libultra… I might back-port all my optimisations to the vanilla game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes offering toggleable ‘fundamental’ mechanics (e.g., old vs improved swimming) preferring a single curated design.
context_findings.quote: I’m kind of against giving players options… I don’t think I want an option for that one.

context_findings.summary: He rarely writes test cases; relies on assumed correctness to save time, accepting later bug-hunt sessions.
context_findings.quote: I never test my code. I just assume it works and it saves me a lot of time.

context_findings.summary: Philosophy: gameplay should emphasise player freedom over explicit guidance (e.g., no aiming guides for cannons).
Moved streaming from Twitch to YouTube because forced ads made Twitch ‘unwatchable’, even for subscribers.
context_findings.quote: On YouTube at least I can decide whether there’s ads… Twitch was just not for me anymore.

context_findings.summary: Works a day job whose ‘team-building’ hours let him play Fortnite on the clock; employer gives two-week vacation in June.
context_findings.quote: My company actually gives me a lot of money for this… two hours every week to play Fortnite… and two weeks vacation.

context_findings.summary: Lighthearted domestic dynamic with spouse Zeina: OnlyFans jokes, shared streaming schedule, house ownership banter.
context_findings.quote: If I have an OnlyFans you’re gonna throw me out?  – Yes… The house is in my name.

biobak.summary: Suggested colour ideas (e.g., red/oil hues) and owns a distinctive ‘biobak pink’; Kaze adjusts textures based on this feedback.
biobak.quote: That red makes it look like running red ash… that was Biobak’s idea.

badub.summary: Composed most of the custom soundtrack, allowing stream playback without copyright strikes.
badub.quote: All of the OST is custom made by Badub, so it actually is not copyrighted.

zeina.summary: Animating the Buzzer boss; presented an early walk-cycle during stream for feedback.
zeina.quote: I duplicated the other animation and tried to do it from scratch… let me know if you have improvement suggestions.

zeina.summary: Acts as on-stream companion; her tolerance will affect potential week-long multiplayer dev streams.
zeina.quote: There might be daily streams while I work on multiplayer, if Zeina can deal with that.

key_stories.title: Zipline Breakage & Collision Bug
key_stories.summary: Zipline mechanics suddenly stopped working. Kaze traced the issue to a months-old collision optimisation that mis-offset ceiling raycasts.
key_stories.challenge: Mario would pass through the zipline trigger and never grab it.
key_stories.process: Added debug prints, identified that the ceiling height was read 160 units too high, located misplaced brackets in find-ceiling optimisation.
key_stories.outcome: Fixed within minutes once located; ziplines restored.
key_stories.key_quote: I messed up the code and I actually never tested it… months later, a bug just occurs.

key_stories.title: Lighting Overhaul Inspired by Odyssey
key_stories.summary: After watching Mario Odyssey footage, Kaze added a camera-aligned light source to brighten moving objects.
key_stories.challenge: Scenes looked too dark and Mario was hard to read.
key_stories.process: Re-enabled camera light, tweaked ambient and directional settings, tested in multiple levels and on N64.
key_stories.outcome: Significantly clearer visuals; new palette experimentation began.
key_stories.key_quote: Even dark cave levels now look not that grim – adding the camera light makes sense.

key_stories.title: Clip-Ratio Performance Trade-off
key_stories.summary: Raising the clip ratio boosts FPS on N64 but causes far-triangle warping.
key_stories.challenge: Need performance without severe graphical glitches.
key_stories.process: Tested Koopa Wave Cove on hardware, observed ‘melting’ geometry, compared FPS, weighed reverting change.
key_stories.outcome: Decision pending; may revert if fix is too costly.
key_stories.key_quote: Clip ratio gives us a few more FPS, but it also causes all of this to happen.
